ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

GOVERNMENT AND GOVERNMENT-AIDED SCHOOL TEACHERS
(Teaching periods and free periods)


    1. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that many teachers, who do extra-curricular duties in Government and Government-aided schools, are given less teaching periods and have more free periods than teachers who do only teaching, and if he will look into the matter.

Column: 511



    The Minister of State for Education (Inche A. Rahim Ishak) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am aware that teachers who perform extra-curricular duties are given more free periods than other teachers wherever possible, and this is as it should be since extra-curricular duties entail a great deal of time both during and after school hours and can be more onerous than teaching in a class. To ensure an equitable distribution of the work load, it is therefore necessary to give more free periods to such teachers. This is the only way to implement successfully Government's policy of laying greater emphasis on pupils' participation in extra-curricular activities to produce a rugged and robust society.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Sir, is the Minister of State for Education aware that in some schools there are senior teachers in charge of administration who hand over the work load entrusted to them to other teachers, who are not senior administrative teachers, to carry out? Thus all these teachers will have to share their work. Therefore, the senior teachers in charge of administration enjoy free periods, whereas the other teachers do not enjoy.

    Mr Speaker: The question does not strictly arise, but if you want to answer it, you may, Inche Rahim.

    Inche Rahim Ishak: If the Member for Paya Lebar has specific complaints to make against any senior teacher for passing on his work load to others, the Ministry of Education will be very glad to receive them.

Column: 511

REGISTRATION CENTRES FOR EMPLOYMENT IN
CONSTITUENCIES


    2. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Labour whether he will consider establishing registration centres of the Employment Exchange in all the 51 constituencies so that unemployed persons may register or re-register themselves, as the case may be, in their respective constituencies and need not

Column: 512

have to incur unnecessary transport expenditure in having to go to the Labour Ministry at Havelock Road.

    The Minister for Labour (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member may not be aware that my Ministry operates at present three employment exchanges. The main one is at Havelock Road, a branch at Bukit Panjang, and another at the Jurong industrial estate. I do not consider it necessary to establish employment exchanges in all the 51 constituencies. It will be a waste of public money to do so.

    Singapore is a small island with excellent and cheap public transport to any part of the island. Any unemployed person can easily go to any one of the present three exchanges and register himself there.

Column: 512

REDUCED ROAD TAX FOR GOODS-CARRYING TRICYCLES


    3. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister of State (Prime Minister's Department) whether Government will consider reducing the annual road tax for tricycles, used for carrying goods, from $43 to $20 the minimum annual tax for motor cycles.

    The Minister of State for the Prime Minister's Department (Tuan Haji Yaacob Bin Mohamed)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, vehicles which carry goods, whether they be tricycles or motor-cars, are licensed separately from vehicles which are not employed for such purposes. The suggestion by the Member for Paya Lebar, if it is considered at all, must be examined from this point of view.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Sir, is the Minister of State aware that a tricycle for carrying goods costs only slightly more than a hundred dollars, but every year its owner has to pay about $43 for road tax?

    Tuan Haji Yaacob(In Malay): Sir, I have stated earlier that if at all the suggestion is to be considered, it will be examined from the point of view of

Column: 513

the use of the vehicle. I would like to suggest to those who use tricycles, to Use motorised tricycles for convenience.

FIRST SUPPLEMENTARY ESTIMATES OF EXPENDITURE FOR
1967 AND FIRST SUPPLEMENTARY DEVELOPMENT ESTIMATES
OF EXPENDITURE FOR 1967


    Order read for consideration in Committee of Supply [Allotted Day].

[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



2.40 p.m.

    The Chairman: The First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1967 contained in Paper Cmd. 25 of 1967. The summary is at the foot of the page. Head 0401 - Ministry of the Interior and Defence. Mr Tang See Chim, amendment No. (1) .

    Mr Tang See Chim (Choa Chu Kang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0401 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead l.*
* The same admendment also stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting.


    It would appear that the grant for the salary increases was given by the Malaysian Government in July 1965 with retrospective effect from 1st of March, 1963. It should, therefore, have been anticipated by the Ministry concerned and provision be made at the beginning of this year for the increase. This has not been done and we are now being asked to vote for a sum of nearly $5 million for the increase.

    Furthermore, I would like to know the total sum involved in this increase.

Column: 514



    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, I fully subscribe to the questions posed by the hon. Member for Choa Chu Kang. Further, I would like to know the exact number of personnel who will be benefiting from such salary increases with effect from 1st March, 1963.

    Secondly, if I remember well, retrospective increases and payments were not to be supported when the previous Minister for Finance, in answer to a speech on a motion on the adjournment by the Member for Telok Blangah, said that the Government was not prepared to give back pay with effect from 1961 in respect of claims by the Public Daily-Rated Employees' Unions Federation. I believe there is no connection with this whatsoever since the decision to give salary increases was made by the Malaysian Government. However, I fully endorse the views of the Member for Choa Chu Kang on this question of the Government having to come to Parliament and ask it to endorse a vote of nearly $5 million.

    The Minister of Defence (Mr Lim Kim San): Mr Speaker, Sir, the amount of expenditure that has to be incurred to pay these increases in salary for the police personnel, which was decided upon by the Malaysian Government when we were part of Malaysia, could have and has been anticipated. It is for purely technical reasons that we did not include it in our Budget, because once provision is made from our own funds, then it makes our position at the bargaining table more difficult. The total increase amounted to $8,112,480, which was fully paid by the Malaysian Government.

2.45 p.m.

    It is an accounting procedure that all receipts should go into revenue and all payments should be voted for under the heads. That is the reason why a supplementary of $4,989,000 is being asked for, because there are savings of $3 million odd from personal emoluments of the police.

Column: 515



    As regards the question of the Member for Punggol, I think he has answered it himself. There is no similarity between back-dating payments for daily-rated workers and police personnel. It is a decision made by the Malaysian Government. It is not something that has been decided upon by this Government or by me.

    I think that answers all the questions.

    Mr Tang See Chim: I am quite satisfied with the explanation by the Minister of Defence, and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendment stood in the name of Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi -

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0401 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 1.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi (Kampong Kembangan)(In Malay): I am not moving.

    The sum of $4,989,450 for Head 0401 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1967.

    Head 0803 -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0803 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 2043.*
* The same admendment also stood in the name of Mr Tang See Chim.


    Mr Speaker, Sir, an extra sum of $233,260 is required to meet an increase in payments because of a bigger number of officers who have retired this year. I would be grateful if the Minister could throw some light on the exact number of officers (with their designations) who have retired this year and, if possible, the reasons for their retirement.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think what is more important is the reason why the retirement of officers was not anticipated at the beginning of the year. As I see it, surely it should

Column: 516

be Government policy, especially in view of the present unemployment situation in the country, to retire all officers compulsorily when they reach retiring age in order to give job opportunities to younger men who enter the labour market.

    Can the Minister give reasons for the increase in payments and why they were not anticipated at the beginning of the year?

    Mr Ho See Beng (Bras Basah): Mr Speaker, Sir, in addition to the two Members who have touched on this matter, I would like to ask the Minister whether the unexpected number of retirements this year was due to the poor pay given to civil servants which hastened their retirement. Usually the Government put them on the Superannuation Scheme, and if that is the case, I feel that the Government should not allow this brain-drain to occur.

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): Sir, the details requested by the Member for Punggol are as follows:

    There were 394 retirements as against 211 the previous year. Eighty per cent of the retirements were due to officers reaching the compulsory age of retirement. The balance were retirements on optional or medical grounds and two officers were retired in the public interest.

    As regards compulsory retirements referred to by the Member for Choa Chu Kang, retirement is compulsory on reaching the age limit - 55 years in most cases; 60 years for those who entered the service more recently. Of course, it does not mean that once an officer retires, he will be lost to the service. In some cases of officers of exceptional merit, we do re-employ them on contract terms, but this again is a very exceptional procedure.

    The Member for Bras Basah suspects that the large number of people retiring may be due to poor pay. I can assure him that the civil service pays very good

Column: 517

salaries. Our difficulty is that whenever there is an advertisement for vacancies, the number of applicants is usually 100 times the number of vacant posts. So I do not think the hon. Member can claim that we are paying poor salaries.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am fully satisfied with the explanation given by the Minister for Finance. On that note, may I beg leave to withdraw my amendment?

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 0803 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 2043.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, to my mind, the amount requested is for officers who have retired this year. As stated by two hon. Members earlier, could the Ministry not have anticipated the number of officers who would be retiring at the end of the year? This means that the Ministry is lacking in efficiency in not having been able to determine the number of officers who would be retiring. The Minister has said earlier that 80 per cent of such officers had to retire compulsorily. If this was known, why did the Ministry not make provision for these people to retire? If this state of affairs carries on, then our Estimates for 1968 will go haywire and there will be further Supplementary Estimates for us to consider at the end of 1968.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, the Member is quite right in saying that there will be further Supplementary Estimates next year. There are Supplementary Estimates every year, and for this year we are lucky to have only one set of Supplementary Estimates.

    As regards the under-estimation, I have said that 80 per cent of the retirements were compulsory retirements. The other 20 per cent were optional retirements and this is the element that is very difficult to estimate from year to year.

Column: 518

Of course, it is also not always possible to allow for more higher paid civil servants retiring in one year as against another year.

    I assure the hon. Member that we are doing our best to have the most exact estimate possible, but in spite of this, mistakes do occur and underestimates do take place, as a result of which this House will certainly have to consider Supplementary Estimates next year.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $233,260 for Head 0803 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1967.

    Head 1002 -

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1002 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead l.*
* The same admendment also stood in the name of Mr Ng Kah Ting.


    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am very glad to hear the Minister for Finance say just now that all estimates are prepared in the most exact manner possible. Unfortunately, the explanatory note to Head 1002 subhead 1 gives an idea that it is not so.

3.00 p.m.

    Every year, each Ministry puts in its estimates and it expects them to be cut down by the Treasury. It is something like bargaining or haggling in the market. I open my price at, say, $3 million. You say, "No, you can get only $2 million." Then at the end of the year, you find that $2 million is not enough and you have to come back to Parliament to get the extra money required.

    That exactly is the position here, Mr Speaker, Sir,I think it behoves the Ministries and the Treasury to come to a certain understanding, so that there need not be any bargaining. What the Ministries want must be stated exactly, and if Treasury want to reduce it, they must

Column: 519

give good reasons. And once the sum is reduced, the Ministry should see to it that it sticks to that figure, instead of, as in this instance, a $2 million reduction, expecting certain vacancies not to be filled, and they had, in the course of the year, filled vacancies up to a sum of $660,000. This is the sum that falls short, and now we are here asked to vote again. Parliament may not be very busy, Sir, but surely this is no way of employing its time!

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have just been given a wonderful illustration of what I would term "inefficiency" on the part of the Ministry concerned in estimating probable expenditure for the year 1967. It is indeed sad for all of us having to come here today to vote for a sum of $660,000 to cover the expenditure incurred.

    From the explanatory note, one would, in the first instance, be happy to note that there was such a thing as "probable under-expenditure" and, therefore, a deduction of $2 million was made. Here again, we have the Ministry of Culture appointing persons to fill the vacancies and today we are billed for $660,000. This is a very big sum of money and I am sure the Minister will inform the House of the number of vacant posts filled, i.e., how many officers have been recruited, to merit the $660,000.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Sir, this is really a technical Treasury point, and so I am answering it on behalf of the Minister for Culture because it deals with methods of estimation and why the Head has been under-estimated and who is to blame, and that sort of thing. Of course, Members must understand that these estimates were passed by hon. Members last year. They cannot, therefore, entirely escape responsibility for it.

    I do not think the Member for Choa Chu Kang got it right when he said that this amount of money is like bargaining between the Ministry and the Treasury. This is about deductions on account of probable under-expenditure.

Column: 520

And, of course, if hon. Members have studied the Estimates for next year which are now before them, they will find that this item is entered in respect of all estimates of expenditure. There are various reasons for this. First, in the case of personal emoluments, where it is the custom to enter the full amount for the year January to December, quite often where this relates to new posts - when you have to fill new posts there are various procedures to follow to ensure that there is no fiddling and that the most qualified persons are appointed to the public service - this, of course, means that you have to advertise in the newspapers. Before you advertise in the newspapers, the qualifications and the terms of the office must be agreed between the Public Service Commission, the Treasury and: the Ministry concerned. This takes time, and as often as not, when you have the time, you find that in many cases you cannot get the people with the requisite experience and qualifications.

    In the case of the Culture Division of the Ministry of Culture, this has been the practice all along since the establishment of television, when they had to recruit many grades of staff which were never found in the public service before, such as T.V, cameramen, newsreel editors, writers, directors -that kind of personnel. And for many years, it has been the experience of the Ministry of Culture to be unable to fill these posts to a very considerable extent. So it is based on past experience that the sum of $2 million had been entered as "probable under-expenditure". Fortunately for us, the Ministry has been able to recruit more successfully this year than in previous years. Hence, the estimate of "probable under-expenditure" proved to be wrong. We, therefore, have to give out the money that they need. I hope this explanation makes the matter clear.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Sir, I am satisfied except for the fact that my colleague, the hon. Member for Punggol, has asked for detailed figures. I wonder whether the Minister could oblige.

Column: 521



    The Minister for Culture and Social Affairs (Inche Othman Bin Wok): Sir, I have the figures with me. This is purely due to reorganisation which was done. There were altogether 74 persons who have been recruited in the Broadcasting Division, including Announcers, two, Engineer, one, Technical Assistant (Superscale), five, Technical Assistant (Special Grade), none, Technical Assistant and Technical Cadet, two, Technicians, 23.

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The following amendment stood in the name of Inche Mohd. Ariff Bin Suradi -

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 1002 be reduced by the whole sum in respect of subhead 1.

    Inche Mohd. Ariff(In Malay): I am not moving, Sir.

    The sum of $660,000 for Head 1002 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1967.

    Question, "That the sum of $5,882,710 shall be supplied to the Government under the heads of expenditure for the public services shown in the First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1967 contained in Paper Cmd. 25 of 1967", put, and agreed to.

    Resolution to be reported.

3.10 p.m.

    The Chairman: The First Supplementary Development Estimates of Expenditure for 1967 as contained in Paper Cmd, 24 of 1967. The summary is on page 4 of the Paper.

    Head 11 -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 11 be reduced by $10 in respect of new subhead 501.

Column: 522



    Sir, I am indeed happy to see the establishment of a regular Outward Bound School at Pulau Ubin. I can well remember that years back we used to send our students to outward bound schools in a neighbouring country. With the objective of building a more robust and rugged society, this establishment of an Outward Bound School comes, in fact, at a very opportune time.

    I myself had the opportunity to visit this Outward Bound School and to see for myself the courses conducted by the authorities there. Seeing young boys and girls undergoing such tough training to meet our objective is indeed a wonderful experience. Now that the Government has realised that such outward bound training is an effective medium to mould our young people into a generation tough and disciplined in body and in mind, I would like to know from the Minister concerned what type of outward bound activities would mould a tough generation disciplined in body and in mind. Further, when was this Outward Bound School instituted and on what basis, in other words, the type of lectures, teachers and management?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Outward Bound School offers courses almost similar to those being offered by the Outward Bound School which was started on an ad hoc basis sometime in 1960 with the help of instructors from the British Army. We actually took over in August this year when preparation was made for the requisite buildings and facilities in Pulau Ubin.

    Coming to the courses themselves, since the hon. Member for Punggol has attended the Outward Bound School -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: I have only visited the school.

    Mr Lim Kim San: - has visited the school, and if he is as curious as he appears to be, surely he would have gone through the hundreds of pamphlets showing the activities of the Outward Bound School - such as canoeing, hiking, camping, rowing,

Column: 523

physical exercises, swimming, the whole lot. These activities are actually planned to instil confidence into the students taking these courses, to let them prove to themselves that they are capable of certain standards of performance which are considered to be the norm for the type of physique that they have.

    I do not think it is possible for me to give a detailed description of the syllabus of the course that is now being drawn up, since the warden, chief instructors, and instructors have only just arrived. But if the hon. Member for Punggol would really like to go into it. I will supply him with all the literature available, including a description of the courses, the whys and the wherefores of the syllabus, the hours they spend outdoors, indoors, camping, etc.

3.15 p.m.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, could the Minister inform the House, since the setting up of such a school, how many courses the school has organised, the number of students, the schools involved - probably the districts? In other words, how many have benefited and, in particular, what is the duration of each course?

    Mr Lim Kim San: Each course lasts from between 18 and 25 days, and since August we have had four courses averaging 40 to 50 students each. They are from the Vigilante Corps instructors, Organising Secretaries of the People's Association, and I think the last batch were teachers from various schools in Singapore.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment since the Minister has fully answered all my questions.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $213,120 for Head 11 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Development Estimates of Expenditure for 1967.

    Head 61 -

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

Column: 524



    That the sum to be allocated for Head 61 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 101.

    Sir, the explanatory note states that a large number of acquisitions have to be completed within this year to meet outstanding acquisition appeals and additional awards made by the Appeals Board, and the sum required is $1.5 million. Could the Minister elaborate on this note?

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Development Estimates for 1967 provide the Land Office with a provision of $4 million under the title "Land Acquisition for General Development". This vote is intended to meet expenditure incurred under the following headings:

    (a) Acquisition or purchase of land for general development, for example, fire sites, urban renewal, parcels of land which may be offered for sale to the State although not needed immediately for a public purpose but whose purchase is deemed desirable for long-term development, for example, the old Admiralty House in Grange Road purchased from the United Kingdom Government in 1963: land in Ulu Pandan purchased in 1967 to allow for the enlargement of a site adjacent thereto; and

    (b) supplementary awards arising from appeals to the Appeals Board or from settlement out of court;

    (c) supplementary awards resulting from surveyings completed after the acquisition indicating that more land has been taken than originally stated and thereby necessitating additional compensation to the owner from whom the land was taken.

    Although an amount of $4 million was provided for, an additional sum of about $1½ million, approximately $1,448,567.89, further particulars of which I will give later, is now required as a result of increases in the awards made by the Appeals Board and in order to complete acquisitions approved this year. This additional sum will enable acquisition proceedings to be finalised in a number of cases this year. Hon. Members will remember that the

Column: 525

Land Acquisition Act, which was long delayed partly because we were in Malaysia, was finally approved sometime last year and made enforceable sometime this year. Many acquisitions have been delayed because we preferred to wait for the new Act to come into force before starting acquisition proceedings. The Court itself has had several sittings this year and made certain awards which, of course, had cost the Government a little money.

    A break-down of the expenditure already incurred and which is to be incurred under the Board this year is as follows: 

 Amount expended:

 

               (a) For general development           $2,284,354.49

               (b) For other projects                $1,945,188.40

                                                     -------------

                   Total                             $4,229,542.89

                                                     =============
The approximate amount required to complete five acquisitions is $1,219,025. These two figures added give a sum of $5,448,567.89. If one subtracts the sum of $4 million from the sum I have just mentioned, the balance will be $1,448,567.89, approximately $1½ million. Sir, I have already bothered the learned Member with figures. I could give him further figures, but I think I will be merely wasting his time.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment, by leave, withdrawn.

    The sum of $1,500,000 for Head 61 ordered to stand part of the First Supplementary Development Estimates of Expenditure for 1967.

    Head 67 -

    Mr Tang See Chim: Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 67 be reduced by $10 in respect of subhead 102.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, what I am going to say also applies to the other subheads in respect of which I have also proposed to move reductions. It would appear

Column: 526
